It would be really interesting to hear what Joseph Romm says at this point. He wrote the 2004 book "The Hype About Hydrogen." His main point was that there were too many challenges to make the hydrogen economy worth pursuing. As Dianna says, there still are many challenges. But we've made significant progress. I remember when blue LEDs were regarded as out of reach, and when everyone said manufacturing LCD displays was so difficult that laptops with 17-inch screens would be prohibitively expensive. Now look where we are...

The biggest reason that ICEVs are still a thing in racing, and why ICEVs will still beat a BEV every time over any distance longer than about a mile is simple: heat. Batteries get hot when you're using them as hard as you would in a race, and that decreases their efficiencies. Plus, refueling time matters in racing, another major drawback to BEVs. FCEVs obviously solve every one of those concerns, so they should be better for racing than both BEVs or ICEVs. The only potential drawback to FCEVs is weight, that fuel cell is essentially one big block of very expensive metal; but as long as you have a better fuel (and hydrogen is a much better fuel than hydrocarbons), you'll still leave ICEVs in the dust. Well, until someone makes an ICEV that burns hydrogen, at least.

H2 is really useful for bigger vehicles where batteries aren't sufficient like long distance jet aircraft, ships, and heavy construction vehicles. Batteries should be sufficient for anything SUV or smaller....but you might see more H2 use in places like the eastern USA that has "real winter" that we don't have in California, since H2 based might perform better in cold temperatures.

Battery powered can be deployed pretty much anywhere because the infrastructure (the electric grid) is already built, whereas H2 infrastructure (a fueling station with a water line that does electrolysis on site) has to built.

Just like you don't put aviation fuel in your car, batteries and H2 will each have their own uses. :)

There are three big issues to overcome with hydrogen fuel cells:

1. Production efficiency.

Hydrogen production is extremely energy intensive. At this point, natural gas is the main input fuel for the hydrogen separation process and it takes an exorbitant amount of natural gas for the process.

2. End use efficiency

Current fuel cell tech doesn’t scale down to POV size well. Cell output to fuel input is hovering around 52% for car size systems today.

3. Precious metals sourcing

Platinum is required in the cell system. This rare element has to be mined from regions which don’t have good humanitarian track records and the mining process is ridiculously challenging for rather minuscule returns.

I sincerely hope that Toyota can overcome these issues. Hydrogen could really be a viable fuel for the future of automobiles. 😁

The Philippines was identified to hold the greatest amount of deuterium deposit in the World somewhere in the area known as Mindanao Trench, the part of the Pacific Ocean just off the shores of Siargao Island. Deuterium gas also known as heavy hydrogen is a heavier and stable isotope of ordinary hydrogen. And is now widely known worldwide as "Fuel of the Future" The amazing thing about deuterium is that at room temperatures or normal atmospheric pressure, deuterium atoms are electrolyzed naturally out of water dispelling hydrogen gas. This natural phenomenal process needs no expensive electric power-consuming electrolysis to artificially separate hydrogen from oxygen in ordinary water. At present, deuterium is used in the production of hydrogen (Li-Hy) fuel now used in Canada,America, Germany and some parts of Sweden to provide fuel for cars, trucks, jet planes, including solid hydrogen for spacecrafts Challenger and Columbia".

I enjoyed watching this presentation. A food distribution wholesaler I worked at made a change to hydrogen. United Natural Food Incorporated in Sarasota,FL , switched all their forklifts from battery to Hydrogen. It eliminates the very expensive batteries, the danger of changing them when they deplete, and potential for accidental breakeage and acid spills.Charging batteries also produces flammable off gassing.

Hydrogen is safer but more importantly, it is more economical for the company.
Instead of the strength of the forklift weakening with a fading batteries, it is full strength until 3% of the Hydrogen left, increasing the time an operatoring time for a forklift. Once the operator has 3% left, he then has only driving functions left so they can get back to the re-fuel station. The station takes far less floor space and a lot less time to re-charge a forklift back to full, as well as a much longer asset life than a battery station.

The funny thing is that hydrogen-powered cars are actually highly inefficient compared to lithium battery-powered cars. The amount of energy lost through hydrogen production, transport and filling is crazy. It is also extremely expensive to produce and store hydrogen for standard filling stations. The fuel cell only extracts 40-60% of the energy from the hydrogen which comes from electrolysis (which is also only around 80% efficient). After all those steps the final energy efficiency is actually very low and even approaching internal combustion engine numbers. An EV lithium-ion battery is around 99% efficient when the energy is extracted. The only real benefit of a hydrogen fuel cell vehicle is that it's quick to fill-up compared to current EV charging times. Once battery technology becomes better (solid-state batteries and higher wattage charging) and we start using more renewable energy, I think hydrogen cars will become completely obsolete.

Where the hydrogen comes from, good question. Generating hydrogen is often thought of as electrolysis of water, getting Oxygen and Hydrogen. It works but isn't very efficient.

Industry uses a technique called Steam Methane Reforming, it's a bit more efficent in producing lots of hydrogen but still not great. The chemical equation is:

CH4 + H20 + heat --> CO +3H2

Hopefully this method would not be used, you might notice that in addition to the hydrogen you get CO, better known as carbon monoxide. Hard to say what the suppliers would actual do, but producing CO is probably counter-productive.

I, along with quite a few other potential buyers, was invited by Toyota to test drive the Marai, when it was released, IIRC, in 2014. I was truly impressed by every aspect of the car, and we also attended a mini-seminar on the total hydrogen use/production of/cost analysis, comparison to gas and BEV, cost-benefit, pollution (almost not measurable) and more. In my mind it passed the litmus test.
The only negative I noticed in the car was it had slightly less power/acceleration than my Camry Hybrid. I understand Toyota has upgraded the electric motor, but have not driven one with the upgrade. The only other negative was there weren't enough fuel stations to drive to S. CA, but that has been remedied also.
The pricing of a Marai is a little lower now and there are over 20,000 Hydrogen Fuel Cell Vehicles in CA now, appx 9,000 of them are the Toyota Marai. When fueling nationwide comes into place I will definitely buy a Marai.

There is no viable carbon capture so ‘blue’ hydrogen is actually worse than just burning the gas in a power station and charging a battery vehicle. This is all just part of the same problem, not the zero carbon emissions future we need.

Knowing what I know know about Toyota, was NOT looking forward to watching this. But I have really enjoyed Physics Girl for a number of years. So... here I am. Trying not to think of Toyota.

Fuel cells were the technology of the future - a few decades ago. Batteries have already surpassed them for automotive use, though fuel cells may have a place in aviation. For automotive use there is really no point in building a new infrastructure to create, distribute, and dispense hydrogen. Hydrogen fuel cell cars were around before BEVs were widely available, but the tech was never ready for prime time. Now BEVs are everywhere - and hydrogen is still not ready for prime time.

We already have electricity at our homes to charge EVs with little to no additional investment. And charger infrastructure outside of the home is being built out at incredible rates - not just Tesla, but many companies building CCS chargers.

EV ranges are already more than sufficient for most trips - I've been driving a Tesla Model X since 2016 and I almost never charge away from home. When I have, on longer roadtrips, it has not been an inconvenience. And that's with a 5+ year old EV - newer models have a lot more range and charge a lot faster. Battery density and capacity keeps increasing, as do charge speeds.

BEVs also give designers more flexibility in packaging the batteries and drivetrain - hydrogen fuel cells have harder requirements for packaging the tanks and fuel cells. Toyota is really alone now pushing hydrogen - and only because they're so late to the BEV game that they're actually lobbying the government to delay BEV adoption.

Hydrogen may still have niches where very high energy capacities and long ranges are required, especially in aviation but also possibly in shipping, rail, and maybe trucking. All of those industries have limited touch points (airports, ports, railyards, and depots/truck stops) which greatly reduces the investment needed to build hydrogen infrastructure. But even there it may be simpler to use e-fuels derived from hydrogen which can plug into the existing distribution systems and don't have the problems of hydrogen - low density as a gas, even at very high pressures, or cryogenic storage as a liquid.

Hey, I just wanted to add some fun facts.

There's been a large push for hydrogen cars in the nordic countries, especially in Iceland. There they had hydrogen buses prior to the financial crack in 2007, and I think they're still trying to get it running fully. Thus hydrogen cars actually predate the modern battery EV.
There's a lot of research going into increasing the hydrogen density (you could look at Torben Jensen from Aarhus university)
The hydrogen is produced via electrolysis. and was originally thought of as a way to store the power generated at night (in Denmark it's a common occurance that our wind turbines generate more power than we can use at night. We often pay Norway to use it to pump water up a mountain (as a battery), but it would be more efficient if we could just store the power ourselves)
There's also a lot of research going into producing H_2 directly from the sun (photocatalysis), that way you'd be able to skip the electrolysis.

Fossil fuels, batteries and hydrogen are just means of storing energy and distributing it where it needs to be used. If we all used electric cars (and I think we will in a few years) we would displace a large polluting factor away from heavily populated cities, which is absolutely great. But since electricity will still be generated via fossil fuels, the overall impact on the climate would be the same. That is to say, electric vehicles are not a panacea that will singlehandedly fix our environmental issues.

That's why I think a much more interesting and vastly more important subject for these videos would be a comparison of pollution between the production of hydrogen and fossil fuels, and a comparison of pollution between the production of hydrogen cars and traditional ICE cars.

Hydrogen cars use hydrogen fuels which are created using electricity. This process of first using electricity to create hydrogen as fuel results in a huge energy lost in comparison to using electricity directly. Yes, the energy density of the resulting fuel is higher, meaning that hydrogen cars can travel slightly farther than an EV, but it also means that for the same amount of mileage, hydrogen cars consume more electricity than a standard electric vehicle.

TLDR; Both use electricity, but hydrogen cars are less efficient with electricity compared to battery-electric cars.

Regarding safety, hydrogen is super reactive (insert Hindenburg gif here) and while I'm sure they have done loads of tests on the COPVs (composite overwrapped pressure vessels) the use of cryogenic hydrogen as a fuel in the use case of a day in day out vehicle isn't a mode which these items has seen before in any other application.

COPVs in a lab environment for example wouldn't ever be expected to endure the stresses of impacts/collisions a vehicle may endure and COPVs used in aerospace for rockets which may have higher impact/stress/load ratings aren't designed to be used continuously or go through hundreds/thousands of pressurization/depressurization cycles like a car fuel tank would be expected to experience.

In the crash tests which verified the integrity of the hydrogen tanks, were they done with the hydrogen tanks full ? half full ? nearly empty ? I'm not sure about COPVs but traditional rocket fuel tanks owe a LOT of their strength to being pressurized (an extreme example being some early rockets being so weak while the fuel tanks were empty they wouldn't support their own weight).

While there's might be someone somewhere who has such a unique set of circumstances that hydrogen makes the most sense for them to power their car, it's undeniable that overwhelmingly for most people in most parts of the world a BEV or PHEV makes far more sense.

Problems with hydrogen vehicles:
* Batteries is still! needed due to restriction in fuel cells power output.
* A hydrogen fuel cell works in a limited temperature range
* Hydrogen is 95% made using fossil fuels (due to cost)
* The cost to store hydrogen is $53 per kilowatt
* Fueling stations are expensive, cost/station is about $2 million. (EV station cost $50k-$150k)
* It costs more to transport hydrogen than gasoline
* As for now, hydrogen filling stations and infrastructure is missing
* Hydrogen is odorless, colorless, highly Flammable and leaks through everything (see: Sandvika, Norway)
* Refueling takes 3 min, but an hour between cars to repressurize.
* Super low tank to tank efficiency. 30% in manufacturing and 26% in storage and distribution.
* Super low well to wheel efficiency. 50% in H2 to electricity and 15% in engine DC/AC.
* Fuel cells wear out fast
* Home refueling is not feasible, due to crazy expensive fuel stations.

"E for Electric" released a video on 12 or 13 August 2021 (title at end of this post) interviewing a tech leader of a company working on chemically bonding hydrogen to a film with hydrogen being released by exposure to a specific light source, giving off pure hydrogen for fuel cell use.

"Fueling" would be to load a fresh hfilm cartridge into an FCEV as the hydrogen storage. The charging for the cartridge can be done from local power from excess available power from renewable sources. A cartridge gets reused a few hundred times (iiuc), and can be recharged in a relatively small facility, so "hydrogen fuel production and storage" would be local or regional almost anywhere. Waste byproducts emerge from the hfilm canister production and recycling (eol hfilm), but are generally pretty low...at least as presented so far. The canister recharge itself does not release unrenewable byproducts.

This would solve the heavy pressure tank issue, the hydrogen leakage issue...it is the smallest atom after all...and make it sufficiently portable that one could carry extra hfilm canisters.

Now this hydrogen storage technology looks to be the most flexible and efficient and likely cost effective path. I'm just waiting to hear cost per kWh and carbon production expense.

The "E for Electric" video is "This BANNED Technology Could Push Hydrogen Cars Over BEVs". "Banned" here because the US Govt locked the patent for nearly a decade because of the potential applicability to a variety of military technologies, requiring export controls and whatnot. Unlocked in 2017 the technology is coming close to commercial viability.

Whole the cartridges would be manageable by a human I suspect the supporting infrastructure would be akin to the automated battery pack swaps seen in China and elsewhere, itself a pretty cool technical solution to long recharge times for BEVs. I'm beginning to think these exchangeable cartridges, whether hfilm or battery packs, will be the successful replacements for the rapid liquid fossil fuel refill of the last 100+ years.

comment_text: OMG YESS MIRAI

🤓 TL:DR - Cheaper (inexpensive) and simpler will always win out, always. HFC is DOA! 💀

💭 Hydrogen for cars is DOA ☠️ because of the cost of the vehicle compared to 🔋 BE (battery electric) and the required infrastructure that has to be built. That said I think larger transportation systems that travel long distances might benefit from hydrogen fuel cells as the infrastructure needs are smaller. Point A to point B and return. Semi-trucks and ships would see an advantage as they have fixed routes mostly. But... as I mentioned, cheaper will always win out.

The first autonomous container ship isn't powered by a hydrogen fuel cell, it's 100% BE. Why? Because it's a short-haul to many ports where they just can plugin as needed and it's lower cost than HFC. I've seen a few BE-powered ferries that have rapid charging systems (RCS) built into the docks by ABB. A computer manages the power connections upon arrival and departure.

What about using HFC? Well, what they have learned is there is an issue with HFCs, and it's called 'Throttle Lag'. While that could be supplemented with batteries to pick up the slack, why not just use batteries in the first place? With increased complexity, there are increased costs. The second-largest ferry system in the world is going all on BE. The routes are set in stone. The infrastructure is cheap to build. Plans to move to BE ferries are already underway.

Aviation would be the only major beneficiary of HFCs. Batteries are very heavy. HFCs make a lot of sense for long-haul aviation applications. Airline and cargo aircraft need to keep the weight low. There is fierce competition between HFCs and BEs. With small short-haul flights, BE wins. A few companies have done their testing and have orders for BE airplanes. Long hauls it's a different story as major airliner builders are making plans to prove their chosen tech will work. I think HFC will win out for long-haul routes.

As for Toyota... It's a fool's errand. All this brainpower is going to waste. If Toyota was using their HFC for marine use, then I would happily install one in my boat. The longer range that takes up less space would out weight the use of BE. But there is a problem. I would have to get hydrogen trucked to all my ports of call. Why not just plugin or use Solar, Wind, and Hydrogen to recharge my batteries? Megayachts are already being designed with these other techs.

Yeah, HFCs are DOA. I wish they could work right now but we are a very long way from making them viable. Had they been invented and used in the 1980s then it would beat out BE. It's like VHS vs Betamax. Betamax is better, but cheaper VHS won out. 😁

There is an upper limit to the energy to be gotten out of a combustion process (the Carnot cycle energy, perhaps?), per unit internal energy of the chemical ingredients of the process. By going to fuel cells, that limit can be exceeded all the way up to the Gibbs free energy level, which is higher. Thus, whenever we can go from burning a fuel to running it through a fuel cell, we can get more energy out of that chemical process.
Unfortunately, the limit of today's fuel cell technology restricts our choices of fuel. The most complex fuel we can "burn" in a fuel cell is hydrogen, the simplest atom (and second-simplest molecule) to be had.
Not to denigrate achievements of fuel cell development. I remember when fuel cells could only work with pure hydrogen and pure oxygen. That we can now use atmospheric oxygen is a great advance.

I think that there is a lot of idealism behind the enthusiasm for all-electric vehicles (which is admirable) but little is ever said of the huge environmental and carbon cost (over the timeframe for completion) of shifting the entire economy of a country (let alone the global economy) from fossil fuel dependence to all-electric, all-renewable energy. There is over 200 years of fossil fuel energy investment in the global economy and that ship will not turn on a dime, it will not reduce global carbon emissions quickly enough to prevent climate catastrophe, and idealism for change always ignores the one big problem: there are too many human beings, consuming too much of pretty much everything, everywhere, all the time. The only way to secure lower carbon emissions through the reduction of fossil fuel dependence is to employ a corresponding, persistent reduction in overall human economy activity.

Reality of hydrogen is that right now nearly all hydrogen is "blue hydrogen" which is made from natural gas via a steam-cracking process that releases a large amount of CO2. "Green hydrogen" (i.e. made from electrolysis) is still too expensive to be remotely economically viable, and with current hydrogen prices that's saying something. It's cool technology, and I think renewable hydrogen has a place in our future, but this technology gets oversold a bit right now as being "clean energy" when it's really not. You're just dumping the CO2 at the refinery instead of out the tailpipe.

Three huge problems with the technology: (1) we are not producing the hydrogen via synthesis from water from electricity generated from wind/solar/nuclear (hopefully we can get molten salt thorium thermal reactors online to do it properly), (2) you need cryogenic hydrogen in order for it to have anywhere near the right volume to energy that is needed, which creates massive problems for cars that will need to be kept in storage for the long term (if you use pressurized hydrogen, then you need vastly more volume of where the fuel goes for the same amount of energy, and you quickly destroy the gas tank it is stored in as the hydrogen permeates through to escape), and (3) you need vastly more electricity expended into making and pressurizing/supercooling the hydrogen than you will get back from the hydrogen, as opposed to batteries which can give you nearly every joule that you put in!

A few very general tips that I have for those wishing to produce a high quality production like this one, follow:  Do not over-crop the sound track because breaks are needed between words, phrases, sentences and paragraphs, for the listener to fully absorb what is being spoken.  Likewise do not speed up the audio-video, for the same reason.  It is also important to use speech intonation carefully, only to enhance communication and avoid arbitrary variations in intonation,  which can be as distracting as long ums, ers and aahs.  Avoid filler phrases.  If speech flourishes are just that then a silent space would better serve the listener.  Listen to some of the great orators delivering their finest speeches, especially those from the mid twentieth century.   Their sentences are rich with meaning, carefully spoken and well spaced. Storing the hydrogen is the HUGE problem with hydrogen as a fuel. Whether cryogenic or pressurized, the leakage is significant and *dangerous*. And the heavy containers make the energy density abysmal.

BUT, this problem is easily solved by using the right carrier. Metal hydrides were tried, and were an improvent. But it turns out the optimal carrier is carbon. Not only does it store the hydrogen with 0 loss, but the carrier oxidizes as it burns, getting recycled, and saving weight as the hydrogen fuel is consumed.

And the energy density is MUCH better than straight hydrogen. For instance, using an 8 carbon molecule stores hydrogen at a greater density (moles/liter) than liquid H2 - and does so at room temperature and pressure!

So if you live in California, HFC vehicles ALMOST make sense. But otherwise, not so much. Way too many issues to be resolved, and they are resolvable issues but the problem is that lithium ion BEVs have progressed so much in the past 10 years in terms of performance and especially cost (about 1/10th as much as they used to be) that there is no way HFC can catch up now even if those issues were resolved, which it doesn't look like.

Think about it: Toyota and Honda have been producing HFC cars and trying to get them off the ground for more than 10 years now and yet still there are only a few tens of thousands of them in existence, with only about 50 refueling stations in all of the US. Anyone who is a student of the Apollo program is aware of hydrogen fuel cells (so this is old technology - in concept) and the fault of which is suspected to have resulted in the Apollo 13 mishap.  The one thing I heard that makes sense, is her comment, "We can't get there by batteries alone."  I'd really like to dig at that.  Hydrogen, for the reason she cited at the beginning of the video that hydrogen is highly reactive and is not found on Earth as H2, means, that unlike fossil fuel, that is really stored solar energy over millions of years, conveniently compressed by geologic processes over that same period, hydrogen must be "mined" - in the same way that copious amounts of electricity is required to melt, then electrolyze bauxite, to produce all the aluminum that we use in modern industrial society, so too must some starter material, such as water, have a great deal of energy input in order to separate the hydrogen.  A childhood demonstration is to take a glass drink container with a narrow neck, and put a few strips of aluminum foil in the bottom, add a couple of tablespoons of lye (sodium hydroxide), then take a ballon, fill it "lightly" (no need to expand the ballon), fasten the mouth of the balloon around the mouth of the drink container, and upend the balloon, dumping the water into the bottle.  The resulting reaction is highly exothermic, and will inflate the balloon.  This is pure hydrogen (plus some water vapor) and will float the balloon nicely for a short time.  As pointed out by the Toyota lady, and Diana's dad, the molecules are so small, the balloon (a typical latex one) will quickly deflate.  And we all know there are NO perpetual motion machines, so the energy required to produce the hydrogen, to compress the hydrogen, to transport the hydrogen, to dispense the hydrogen, then factor in the inefficiency in the electric power chain, and the motive energy to move the car and occupants will be far less than the input.  Of course, if the hydrogen production can benefit from otherwise waste energy, and renewables, and fusion when that gets here - that'll be another story.  I would dearly love to see the business forecast Toyota is using to justify investing in hydrogen.  And BMW spent a boatload of R&D on hydrogen. I think most of that is on the shelf.  ONLY if we truly "can't get there by batteries alone" would the huge investment in a hydrogen infrastructure on which any vehicle manufacturer would depend, make sense.

One massive draw-back with batteries, is the availability of the raw materials required to make the current mass produced batteries. Currently, Lithium is still the number one sought after resource for manufacturing high performance and long lasting batteries. And the more car manufactures turn to sourcing these batteries, as they increase the number of EV models in their ranges, the more pressure is put on the Lithium resources available in the world. While Lithium needs to mined and can only be obtained from certain areas in world, Hydrogen is basically available everywhere. Yes, it may be a costly process to obtain Hydrogen and store is safely in volumes, but the fact that the pressure on Lithium is increasing, due to increased demand, makes Hydrogen propulsion a potentially viable alternative still!

Here is in an interesting observation. Petrol fuel, which is highly flammable, maybe even more so than hydrogen, is stored in a "plastic" fuel tank in your car, while Hydrogen has to be stored in an armored tank... Which means, driving a Hydrogen car these days is far safer than a normal ICE car, if safe storage of the energy source is a concern!
I think, somebody clearly did not like that, simply mixing Oxygen with Hydrogen to produce water while providing propulsion, was a good idea... Perhaps somebody (or somebodies) with a HUGE interest in the mining sector??? I clearly remember the 'activists' about the safety concerns of transporting Hydrogen, just a few years ago. But thanks to those activists, having Hydrogen fuel in your car has since become much safer than having flammable petrol fuel swashing around in a 'plastic' and relatively easy pierce-able tank.

Dear Physics Girl,
Hydrogen (next to Helium and Neon) will heat up when expanding. The reason for the cold is that to fill up your FCEV the gas is pre cooled. If this is not done, the expanding gas in the tank will heat up to much and become dangerous. So that is why the nozzle is cold. There is a protocol between the HRS and the FCEV car that determines how fast it can fill up based on the current temperature of the gas and how empty your tank is.

I apologize if someone has already articulated this, but many of the top comments show a concern for inefficiency, BEV vs. FCEV, etc.

I do agree that it is essential that we have this information, and I think a beautifully thorough form of it should be made fully transparent, as digging through it drives innovation. And it is also true that certain technologies will eventually dominate the market; so, if BEV ends up being the best, it will naturally outcompete others (especially in the hands of big players, as their bottom lines and shareholders will not tolerate dead-end technologies for long).

However, this does not mean that exploring and refining competing, currently inefficient technologies has no place. In fact, current data-development and -mining models (that which drives the continued technical revolution) almost require we, as a society of innovators, iterate (often all the way to market) through countless "failed" technical frameworks. The information gathered through this process, especially if it is fed back into global developmental models, can drive key opportunities that may lead either to a (or a series of) breakthrough(s) that makes hydrogen competitively viable or that triggers the discovery of something completely new, something that outperforms anything currently known.

We are living in an age where the challenges are planetary vast, the answers to meet them unknown, and the paths to them unknown. We cannot afford to single-mindedly invest in today's best technology and assume it will meet the needs of tomorrow. The speed of iteration, innovation, and global-system needs have scaled to an unprecedented degree, and I feel that we must strive to open our minds to the pace at which ever-accelerating technical systems can identify, vet, fail, innovate, and introduce (to repeat the cycle) each next idea.

Honestly, it doesn't matter how they drive or how they work. Hydrogen is a total non-starter.

1) Hydrogen costs 3 to 4 times what gasoline costs - 12 times more than electricity.
2) Hydrogen manufacture produces more CO2 than gasoline production. So these cars pollute HORRIBLY. If they switch to hydrolysis of water, then the cost of hydrogen will be 40 times the cost of electricity.
3) If you live outside of California, there are NO hydrogen fuelling stations...NOT ONE! So if you live (say) in Texas, there is no possibility of owning a hydrogen car...but will anyone build a bunch of hydrogen stations in a place where there is not one single hydrogen car. No! Hydrogen filling stations are VERY expensive and need a ton of environmental impact studies. Nobody is going to build one in a place where there are zero customers. This chicken and egg problem dooms the hydrogen car.
4) Maintenance on a hydrogen car is HIGH, the fancy membrane and it's catalyst need to be replaced regularly...this is EXPENSIVE. Electric cars need zero maintenance.
5) The driving experience of a hydrogen car is (at best) identical to an electric car...not better. But actual hydrogen cars have sucky performance.

Electric cars are MUCH more reasonable. You can charge at home...this is FANTASTIC. There is virtually no maintenance. An electric charging station is super-cheap, and fits onto any existing parking lot.

Fuel cells can't be recharged from regenerative braking, regenerative acceleration or rooftop solar panels. https://www.slideshare.net/PDiCEOThaneHeins3240/final-version-electric-vehicle-regenerative-acceleration-innovation-presentation-for-international-ev-oems RegenX generator can create electricity without mechanical energy input, because armature reaction is delayed in time domain, and current start to flow, when magnet has already passed top dead center of the coil. There is 20 magnets on rotor disk. When it rotates with 3600 RPMs, frequency is 1200 Hz. Regenerative acceleration effect occurs above critical minimum frequency, around 1kHz. Delayed Lenz effect proves that energy can be created. Energy is created in every electric generator. In conventional electric generator, created energy is used to do negative work and decelerate rotor. In RegenX generator, created energy is used to do positive work and accelerate rotor. Regenerative acceleration technology is solution to battery energy density problem, and too heavy battery problem.

This is fossil fuel industry propaganda. PhysicsGirl is being hoodwinked. Things to remember about the hydrogen con game: 1) So-called green hydrogen is being pushed hard by the fossil fuel industry. They are desperate to get hydrogen adopted widely because they know that it will be impossible to supply hydrogen from electrolysis in industrial quantities. Then they (the fossil fuel people) will step in and say reforming methane is the only way. Reforming methane produced huge quantities of CO2.
2) Water vapor, produced either by burning or via a fuel cell, is actually a worse green house gas than CO2. It just doesn't stick around as long as CO2.
3) Electrolysis of water takes a lot of electrical energy but far more energy is needed to compress and cool it to make it transportable and usable. For fuel cells, the hydrogen needs to be compressed to 700 bar - that's the same as the pressure at 7000 meters (23,000 feet) deep in the ocean. It take's a lot of energy to do that compression.
4) Hydrogen oxidizes explosively. A leaky hydrogen tank in your mirai (and they all leak because it's impossible to store hydrogen in any container because the atom is small enough to seep through metal) will fill your garage and house with hydrogen and with a small electrical spark - like a light switch being turned on - and your house and you will be destroyed.
5) For fuel cells the hydrogen has to be very pure otherwise the very expensive rare metal catalysts will be ruined. So it's not possible to put smells or colors in the hydrogen make leaks noticeable - (see point 4).

People were conned by the diesel hype. Hydrogen is the latest fossil fuel industry con game. For the sake of the planet and humanity we must not fall for it.

When considering the efficiency remember it is not always valid, although it provides targets for improvements. From memory the Internal combustion engine extracts around 18% of the energy in the fuel/gas but you never hear it criticised as much as renewable sources. Solar cells at best are doing 20% efficiency except for the expensive ones used in space, ie they only convert 20% of the energy in light to useable energy. The point is 20% of something is 20% more than nothing, and solar and wind cost next to nothing. The full picture is established by looking a the whole system including the embedded energy, mining and collection, leakage and wastage, health impacts and other externalities. Then the cost vs benefits a user may use to choose, may still be excluding externalities. If the fossil fuel energy sources paid for their impact they would be much more expensive.

An important aspect of hydrogen is also its weight, you carry very little weight with a full hydrogen vehicle, I believe as little as 5kg with Fossil fuels about that of 75% the weight of water (per litre) eg 40kg for a tank.

Hydrogen key benefits is its energy to weight ratio, its high intencity. Of course the details about how we make it in the form we need is the big question. As a result Hydrogen stands to be the missing component of transferring renewables into transport and into high energy systems like smelting and glass production. It may also server as a high density storage method.

I am yet to explore the details but a hybrid Battery/Hydrogen/electric car may prove ideal from reducing range anxiety through to improving health in high traffic areas (any city) to name a few.

Our economies can only prosper with such innovations and we must stop propping up the old ways. There is no reason the fossil fuel industries can not prosper from this innovation them self, after all it is just business. To defend the indefensible, is to also be indefensible.

Over the short term, BEVs make a lot more sense if we want get fossil fuels out of transportation ASAP. It's not that BEVs aren't without their drawbacks (e.g. the added weight, the resource intensity of manufacturing large batteries, etc.). It's that putting in hydrogen infrastructure will be orders of magnitude more difficult/expensive. Electricity is ubiquitous. No...high-speed charging isn't available everywhere, and we need to triple the capacity of the grid to support a total changeover, but it is available everywhere (and charging at home is just so convenient). Hydrogen stations, on the other hand, are basically nonexistent outside of CA.

I really liked the Chevy Volt as a concept, and was disappointed to see GM kill it. I'd like to see it brought back, but with hydrogen as the range extender rather than gasoline. I still think it has merit: a car with a modestly-sized battery (i.e. just big enough to cover an average day's commute and allow for some regenerative braking) with hydrogen to allow it to go hundreds of miles further (i.e. for days when you don't have time to recharge or on long road trips).

As an engineer, I can attest to the limitations of tests like that. There's always a weak point (e.g. I would guess the fill and feed valves in this case) and a bad bounce or asymmetric impact can exploit that. And they usually don't test the case where you get rear-ended by a semi-truck and squashed into another in front of you. The argument is, you're probably going to die even if your tank doesn't explode, but what about the truck drivers and bystanders? I'm not sure I'd want a hydrogen fill station located anywhere close to my home either. Seems like a prime target for a terrorist attack. Also, the prospect of going off-road in a hydrogen-powered Jeep doesn't appeal to me.

That being said, hydrogen tanks have been transported safely for many decades now so adapting that technology to passenger cars is not a big stretch. Just be prepared to swap your flashy racing stripe decals for danger signs and the like.

Hmm … a correction … it’s not a chemical reaction is it? It’s an atomic reaction. Hydrogen and Oxygen are not chemicals, they are atomic elements.  And FUEL CREDIT means someone else pays for the fuel, but more importantly is the infrastructure for hydrogen.

Are they working on building hydrogen from solar electric hydrolysis infrastructure? Now, most hydrogen is produced by cracking methane, which is not a very environmentally helpful change. (Where does that carbon in the CH4 go?) Also, your losing energy in the compression process. Thermodynamics is a bi...ummer. If you took all the energy needed to make the hydrogen and compress the hydrogen and put it in a battery, you could drive a lot further. The laws of physics make this an inherently inefficient process.  For things like planes and rockets where power to weight is critical hydrogen makes sense. Not so much for cars. Also, all the work on making an indestructible hydrogen tank is because the compression wave speed from a compressed hydrogen explosion is similar to that of TNT or other high explosives. As I recall, Elon Musk was having trouble with expansion and contraction of his composite tanks for Starship, which is why he switched to stainless steel. Temperature change with compressed gases puts extreme thermal stress on composites, and I'm pretty sure, plastic, carbon fiber, and glass fiber all have different expansion contraction properties when exposed to temperature change.....not to mention the epoxy resin the fibers are embedded in.

Electric vehicles themselves don't do anything for net emissions!  They just allow the energy conversion process to move from a million inefficient internal combustion engines to larger centralized more efficient power plants.  In most cases, electric cars still burn fossil fuels; they just do it somewhere else!  The transmission and storage inefficiency of that power along with the environmental impact of producing a more expensive car (eg. platinum catalysts, et al) have to out weight the energy conversion efficiency benefits for net zero.  The biggest efficiency of electric vehicles is the spare capacity of power plants during night-time hours can be leveraged w/o having to significantly expand the grid (for now).

As far as I know most of the hydrogen available today for commercial purposes isn't produced through hydrolysis ("green" hydrogen). Hydrolysis is an energy expensive process where you have to apply high energy to a water solution in order to break its atoms apart.

Instead, most of today's hydrogen is produced by burning methane. You can either do carbon capture on the process ("blue" hydrogen), even though, let's be frank, processes for carbon capture at this scale aren't even available, or just no carbon capture ("grey" hydrogen).

In other words, your green vehicle consumes fuel that was generated by burning a potent greenhouse gas.

I agree that we should look at things on the long term though. In the future electrolysis is likely to become cheaper (mostly because we're likely to have energy surpluses from renewable sources that we can use to split water), and when it does hydrogen will also become greener without having to change the technology already built on top of it. Just like the environmental impact of an electric car is proportional to the ratio of renewables that was used to produce the energy to power it. It makes sense to invest in technologies whose environmental cost only consists of the environmental cost required to power them, because once you can produce that energy in cleaner ways the vehicle becomes greener as well, without having to change its design. But for now we have to be aware of this simple truth: as things stand today hydrogen isn't yet a green and zero-emissions technology.

Thanks for the videos. It's sad to see that in the comments, many people seem to be missing the forest for the trees. Massive scale green hydrogen production is inevitable for ammonia and methanol production, the former of which is necessary to support agriculture. There are 250GW of green hydrogen electrolysis projects currently in the works, so pearl clutching over where the hydrogen comes from seems a bit shortsighted, for the exactly the same reasons that criticizing BEVs for the source of their electricity would be. Green hydrogen isn't a choice, it's a necessity if we want to feed everyone without using fossil fuels.

The comments on the relative efficiency of fuel cell vehicles versus BEVs are similarly misguided, given that every year, California alone already curtails enough electricity to charge 25 million, 100kWh battery electric vehicles, and no one bats an eye. When VREs like wind and solar provide the backbone of our energy generation, we're not going to worry about the well-to-wheels efficiency of fuel cells, because we're going to have far more than enough to go around. Denmark already produces 40% of its electricity demand on average through wind, but this spikes up to 140% during periods of overproduction. If Denmark wanted to meet even 80% of its electricity needs through wind with some level of statistical confidence (say, 80% confidence) it will average more than 100% of its demand every day. At a macro level, this also applies to larger regions like the EU or the US, because they'll still want some level of statistical confidence in their ability to provide X units of power from variable sources.

And this is before getting into other issues with BEVs, like coupling between charging times and generation: to charge a BEV with a 100kWh battery in 3 minutes like you would a normal ICEV would require a 2MW charger, which is non-trivial. You can avoid this if trickle charging is everywhere, but then you still need extensive grid upgrades on practically every street corner for those who use on-street parking. The point is: fast charging is only partly about the technology in the battery -- the rest is up to the grid to either be able to produce MWs on demand from variable sources, or to pursue extensive upgrades so that people in apartments don't have to sit at a fast charger for an hour every week, because they can charge on any street corner. Hydrogen decouples this whole process, since you have massive, steady demand and don't need to provide instantaneous changes in power, and it's a source of energy that can be shipped around. It's not clear to me whether hydrogen is necessarily better for transport than ubiquitous chargers, but it's 100% clear to anyone who's paying attention that we'll be making and shipping a huge amount of hydrogen around anyway, so it almost certainly has a place somewhere in the transport equation.

The lady who said that you could leave the car in the garage for your entire life and the tank would still be full is either naive, lying or is being creative with the definition of "full". It is impossible to constrain hydrogen as it's molecules are smaller than any other elements so regardless of what material you make the tanks from there is going to be leakage. It is physically impossible to restrain something much smaller than what the intermolecular distance is in the restraining object. It's a bit like trying to restrain golf balls with a basketball hoop or water with a woolen jumper. The hydrogen tanks have a rated permeation rate in the range of litres of H2 gas per hour. This works out to something like 0.1g of gas per hour. The gas tank holds about 5kg so you are theoretically losing a tankful of gas in about 6 years. This permeation rate does change as the pressure in the tank changes but personally I feel that my lifetime is going to be much longer than 6 years it takes to empty the tank let alone the much shorter amount of time where you could still call the tank full.
Dianna your father is right. The salesperson is wrong. It's not a high rate of leakage but it's still significant and a lot of the regulations for hydrogen cars are to do with the leaked gas.

There seems to finally be reliable studies on electric vehicles (the battery, “BEV” type). Apparently a BEV, when coming out of the assembly line, has already polluted as much as a diesel car at or near the end of its life. This is due to two factors: the technology used to produce electricity, and the battery manufacturing, both extremely polluting. Not everybody knows it, but in some places they produce electricity by burning coal. BEVs have only displaced the problem, they have not solved it. Any volunteer to go say that to Elon Musk and his army of followers? It seems to me, therefore, that the challenge of the fuel cell technology is the ability to produce hydrogen without polluting the planet. In Europe, this is slowly becoming the technology of choice, and I am betting many more will follow. So my question is: how are we going to mass-produce hydrogen without just displacing the pollution yet another time?

One concern I have for hydrogen batteries is he limits on energy density and hydrogen's tendency to get through barriers. Hydrogen is naturally a quantum object so given the laws of quantum mechanics I don't think you can ever say that there is no way for it to leak since given the form of the Schrödinger equation I can't see how you could reduce the probability of tunneling to zero. You can get it astronomically small such that the limit approaches zero but the probability itself never goes to zero.

Yes it's largely semantics but the probability of escape should be linked to the energy contained within the tank since atoms as small as hydrogen are extremely quantum objects. And hydrogen gas is very corrosive while materials can be used to inhibit this corrosion I wonder what the total lifetime of one of these fuel cells really is and how the probability of escape changes over the course of its operational lifetime.

There is also the drawback that like all electric power sources it is only as clean as the electricity used to split hydrolysis. Anyway the real pros at splitting water are plants which effectively use light to split apart water to fix that hydrogen with carbon in order to capture energy from the sun into chemical form. Plants are far from perfect but there might be chemical insights to improve the reaction efficiency for example.

Hi Dianna, love your work.  You really must ask Toyota HOW H2 will be produced?  If H2 is from fossil fuels, then FCEVs are a terrible idea for obvious reasons.  If H2 comes from water electrolysis, then this is a poor idea due to poor overall conversion efficiency.  I did an "Musk-like" first principles estimate and found that BEVs are significantly more efficient than FCEVs even when assuming best conversion efficiency for electrolysis, pressurization, and FC electric conversion.  I'd really love to hear what Toyota has to say about this.  My feeling is that Toyota will be very cagy about this aspect of FCEV technology because there is really no good answer to this question.  Until H2 can be produced, distributed, and used in an FCEV at lower cost than BEVs it is doomed to failure due to competition with ever decreasing costs of batteries in particular and BEVs in general.  The only good thing about Toyota doing an FCEV is that at least they are making an electric drivetrain to operate with the FC.  That will save them some time to develop a BEV drive train once they realize their unfortunate choice.  IMO, Toyota should be the BEV leader, but unfortunately they are almost dead last at this time.  If they don't change their attitude soon, we could see them go out of business within the next 10 years.

I'm sure you bring it up later, but my informed opinion on Fuel Cell tech is that it's great, it's just being used in the wrong application. To shorten a long analysis, batteries and high demand applications (high power consumption) really don't mix. A few pieces of evidence to support my case include the first Gen Tesla Model S being unable to do any track time because it would be in a "power reduced" state in the first lap around Leguna Seca, and the Cybertruck towing it's max rating could go only about 50 miles, before needing to stop and charge for 2 hours. Neither of which would happen to a fuel cell car. the Fuel cell doesn't mind high demand like batteries do, and even if it did only make it 50 miles towing, it's still only 10 minutes to fill up, not two hours.

The cost is still an issue (and would get worse in these applications), but I believe that's where fuel cells have a future.

"Toyota is not responsible for the operability of third party fuel stations or the availability of hydrogen fuel".

Well, of course they don't they don't want to be responsible for the part that dictates why we'll never have hydrogen cars.

Battery EVs immediately answer your questions about range. Sure, there might be more or less superchargers in a certain area, but worst case scenario you can just charge it at home or on any regular outlet, and things will get better with time.

Meanwhile, Hydrogen has a severe*, so far *unsolved problem with availability. And the problem is fairly simple: Hydrogen is expensive and slow to manufacture. The two ways this could work is either each gas station makes its own hydrogen, or hydrogen is centrally manufactured and distributed, just like gas. The first case would never work, first because the initial investment is *massive*, and there are no customers, and second, because when there are enough customers, a gas station can't make hydrogen fast enough to supply them. What about centrally manufacturing it and distributing it like gas? Well, there are again no answers here. There isn't enough hydrogen production to go around for any significant amount of vehicles, so you're guaranteed to see prices fluctuate UP the more hydrogen cars there are. Just like gas. And there's no WAY that supply could keep up with demand if there was any serious demand.

So, basically, the only way hydrogen cars could work is if there was only a few select vehicles with a steady, predictable requirement, such as the buses on a city or trucks.

100% GREEN hydrogen is available today in California. Find the stations here: https://cafcp.org/stationmap

FCEV using green hydrogen will emit 79%-80% lower life-cycle green house gas emissions than a comparable gasoline car and it is being done today.

A BEV using 100% green electricity will emit 81% lower life-cycle green house gas emissions than a comparable gasoline car, but the grid is only 10-20% green at night when BEVs are charging: http://www.caiso.com/TodaysOutlook/Pages/supply.html When is California's goal to have a 100% renewable electrical grid? 2045: https://focus.senate.ca.gov/sb100/faqs

Even the worst hydrogen you can fuel up with today (33.3% green and 66.7% blue) emits 72.44% less life-cycle green house gas emissions than a comparable gasoline car. Whereas the average BEV in the United States will emit 57% - 68% less life-cycle green house gas emissions than a comparable gasoline car. This means driving a BEV will contribute more to carbon emissions than driving a FCEV today.

Just as a guess as to why Hydrogen Fuel Cells are being pursued, I imagine it has to do with supply and safety. With electrolysis, we have a near limitless supply of Hydrogen for a relatively small amount of power. Hydrogen doesn't have attenuation problems when transporting it. And most importantly, Hydrogen isn't nearly as dangerous to store as a giant Lithium-Ion Battery. Clearly they've done as many tests as they can to make sure the hydrogen tanks don't rupture, and I'm sure they've done the same with the Lithium-Ion cells in general electric cars, but in the hypothetical situation that a tank or battery does rupture, it seems the tanks are designed in a way that an explosion doesn't really happen, just a depressurization. Compare that to a Lithium-Ion battery; it's just not possible to design the battery in a way that if it ruptures you don't end up with a massive fire.

Partial oxidation of methane:

CO + H2O → CO2 + H2

Shame on you, Diana! I can forgive a layperson for thinking hydrogen fuel cell cars are green, but you're a physicist, you should know better! It costs more energy to make hydrogen than you get out of it, that's simple physics. We aren't harvesting any natural hydrogen and that's a well-known fact. So then it comes down to where the energy comes from. If Toyota takes it directly from the power grid, then it's allocatable power which, due to all green sources being non-allocatable means it comes 100% from oil, coal, and/or natural gas. That's a best-case scenario in which its maximum possible efficiency is some value less than a petroleum-burning car. But that's also pure fantasy. The power demands are going to be sky-high, there's no way they're just going to get it from the power company. They're going to have on-site generators, and those generators are going to run as cheap as Toyota is allowed to run them. You know exactly what that means: coal. Don't trust what Toyota says, it's patently clear that they will make these cars quite literally the least green form of transportation that has ever been mass-produced within our lives.

Why? Because of physics, Diana ;-)

Assuming green H2, the price per km will always be much higher than that of a BEV. There are too many energy losses in the entire process: 1) to make hydrogen from green electricity 2) to transport it 3) to compress it and 4) to convert it back into electricity inside the fuel cell. The total efficiency, albeit better than that of ICE, is at most 30% of that of a BEV because of all these conversion steps with inherit losses.

The only argument that remains is that you can refuel H2 faster, but that argument also seems less and less important with the latest generation of superchargers. Add to that the fact that we now have hundreds of thousands of charging stations all over the world and only a handful of hydrogen stations and I think we can safely say: hydrogen cars will never win this race.

Toyota deserves a lot of respect for the development at the time with the hybrid Prius, but they have now completely lost their way with this strategy.

If you really want to know about the Electric Economy and EV's then you need to watch Fully Charged: https://www.youtube.com/c/fullychargedshow/videos They cover the whole thing, including hydrogen.

As an example they visited the Orkney Islands off the north coast of Scotland. They have so much wind and solar that they sell the excess to the mainland! They have also banned the ferries and cruise ships in their harbours from running their diesels while in the harbour. If they can't plug in to shore power then they can't come in! They are working on converting ferries to fuel cell electrics. Some of the ferries are already diesel electric so the are taking out the diesels and fitting hydrogen fuel cells. The hydrogen is manufacture from renewables so fully green. They are also developing small modular hydrogen plants so that even small harbours can service fuel cell powered ships.

The optimum future I think is BEVs for city transport, and HFCs for range extenders in trucks and ships. There are now a handful of sailing yachts which are completely electric. This is one: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXbWsGV_cjG3gOsSnNJPVlg The boat has an electric motor with a special screw. Under sail they can use the motor as a generator to charge the batteries. One of the ferry crossings between Denmark and Sweden now has BEV ferries with special robotic charge points at each terminal that connect automatically as soon as the ferry has locked on to the ramp. In two years they saved enough on not buying diesel to pay for the installation.

Finally beware of Toyota. They are actively rubbishing BEVs and lobbying against government subsidise and investment in infrastructure. They were the market leader, but new management invented the "Self Charging Hybrid" and they have now bet on hydrogen. They are the biggest car and light truck manufacturer in the world so the have a lot of pull. The Chinese however have the BEV transport environment pretty much sewn up. Shenzhen made the decision to go fully electric and within a year they had done it. They replaced ALL their buses, more than 20,000 and ALL the taxis withe BEVs. They swapped out the buses overnight! They now have more electric buses and taxis than the whole of the rest of the world.

From what I understand, there is a theoretical limit to the efficiency of the conversion of electricity to hydrogen which is fairly low, in other words turning electricity to hydrogen is kind of a waste. Thus the only way to produce hydrogen from electricity that makes sense is to produce it with electricity coming from renewable, green, sources (that's a given, right?) which would be otherwise wasted, because there is almost always a better usage of the electricity produced than storage as hydrogen. An example of a good "source" of energy would be a wind turbine working during the night, when people sleep and the demand on electricity is low.

If you combine the poor efficiency and the low availability of these renewable sources, I don't see how it's possible to imagine replacing even a tiny fraction of all the vehicles of the world with hydrogen vehicles.

Of course you can produce hydrogen with hydrocarbons, but that's not renewable, and it produces a massive amount of CO2

This is all well and good but the production of the hydrogen is problematic. There are 2 ways hydrogen is produced currently. The expensive way is by electrolysis of water. This uses electricity to separate the hydrogen from the oxygen. The electricity required to do this is more than the reaction in the hydrogen fuel cell vehicle gives back. 60% of the power in the US power grid is produced from burning carbon in one form or another. Using hydrogen from this source is little better than plugging your battery powered electric car into a diesel powered generator.

The other way to produce hydrogen is cheap. Synthesis gas, a mixture of hydrogen, carbon monoxide, and a small amount of carbon dioxide, is created by reacting natural gas with high-temperature steam. Okay so hydrogen tanks are a twofold problem, 1. hydrogen is really small and wants to leak out of everything, 2. hydrogen is not dense and so it wants to be very far away from itself. This means that the fuel tanks have to be VERY HIGH pressure, and at high pressure the hydrogen wants to push through the walls of the tank even more, which isn't counting the part where now you have an extreme pressure pressure vessel driving around the road filled with highly flammable material.

Then hopefully they mentioned the issue with the cost of the fuel cell itself. Last I heard the platinum energy catalyst that recombines the hydrogen and atmospheric oxygen is a wear item and it's very expensive. That means it's fine for a spacecraft where cost is less important than reusability, but in a car that's more problematic. And then you don't want to talk about the cost of platinum.

Good news, hydrogen is the most plentiful element in the universe as well as on earth, but here it's never found as raw hydrogen. You can find it in hydrocarbons (fuel) which was thought of as a potential way of getting it to your fuel cell, but water, being 2 parts hydrogen, is relatively simple to separate into it's elements, except for it's very energy intensive, and then consumes water which is actually most of the time better used for food or drinking than it is to be converted to oxygen and hydrogen.

And then as others have mentioned there aren't any places where you can readily pick up some raw hydrogen, it's not like all the gas stations in the country are going to start installing hydrogen pumps. This is where battery electric vehicles absolutely destroy hydrogen, EVERYONE has electricity, or if they don't it's relatively cost effective to build a solar array at home just to recharge your car.

All told these are the reasons why Hydrogen Fuel Cell cars have always been 20 years away for the last 50 years, and it's not likely that Toyota will recoup their investment in it anytime in the next 50 years even. We have to applaud them for the effort, but it's really a dead end, electrons are cheaper, lighter, easier to generate, much easier to store and transport, and lightweight transportable batteries are going to get a lot better in the next 10 years. Lastly platinum is a lot more rare than is lithium.

I appreciate the learning opportunity, but hydrogen isn’t the way forward. It has all the issues that gasoline does except for the emissions, and worse infrastructure problems than BEV charging has ever had. We'd need to build out an entire industry and infrastructure for H2 generation, storage, transport, and fueling stations, not to mention the cars themselves. BEVs are already here, can be charged literally almost anywhere (if there's a 120V outlet available, it'll work, although slowly), and the existing charge station (L2 and L3) infrastructure is improving by the day.

It’s also less efficient than BEVs - it takes electricity to generate hydrogen (3-4kWh to get 1kWh worth of H2 out, from what I remember reading). It just plain makes more sense to pump that 3-4kWh directly into a battery, rather than adding thermodynamic losses by adding another conversion step into the process.

Hydrogen is a futuristic pipe dream from decades ago, it has no realistic future anymore for person- to family-scale transportation. Toyota needs to let go of its sunk cost fallacy.

I drove a Mirai for over a year. It's a great vehicle but the fueling infrastructure wasn't there yet. There were lots of occasions where stations were impacted by weather phenomena affecting hydrogen-producing plants, causing hydrogen car owners to not be able to drive their vehicles. Toyota offered gasoline car leases in the meantime. Also, the lines at the fueling stations were problematic at times too, because there were only 4-5 stations in my entire metro area. Overall, great car but it will be more convenient in a few years when more hydrogen stations pop up.
